column4: For instance, I open up my home folder, and I have a file with an extension of .log, and I right-click on the file and I get "Open With" and several options, but none of those options work for me
I choose "Open With Other Application" but the application that I want to use doesn't appear there either
file extensions in Linux don't mean much
what app do you want to use?
the program is wxmacmolplt, it does not come with the standard Ubuntu distribution nor is it on the Ubuntu servers
bit of a hack but you could add: TextEditor;    to the end of the categories line in the .desktop file for the app in /usr/share/applications
where would I add it in this file?  It looks like this file has the format of variable=value
oh never mind, I just read your last comment, thanks
that didn't seem to work, wxmacmolplt still doesn't show up when I right-click on a .log file
try logging off and on
hmm is there a way to do it without restarting my session?  I have a job running that I would prefer not to interrupt
not sure, i'd just wait for the job to finish. Maybe they are read periodically...
unfortunately the job will take several more days to finish.  Guess I will try it out then.
wow, large job!
it is a quantum chemical calculation
dang
same way you added the TextEditor   option I gave..
but I don't see a mime type variable in the .desktop value, what is the precise syntax?
look at some of the others, you will see the category. With you stating this sort of thing I'm doubting you did what I sugegsted earlier at all...
no I did, because I just had to append it to the end of an existing variable, but there is no mime type variable in the .desktop file
look for: MimeType=    in the .desktop file and add what glitsj16 suggested
use the search function in the text editor you are using, or just add the line in full
and glitsj16 unfortunately the MimeType trick didn't work either
